step1.sentence: She woke up an hour early to get a head start on her presentation before the rest of the team arrived.

step2.story: Marcus signed up for the coding bootcamp three weeks before it officially began. He used the extra time to get a head start by learning the basics of Python on his own. When class started, he was already ahead of most of his peers.

step3.story: Every Sunday evening, Priya spent an hour reviewing the upcoming week's tasks. It was her way of getting a head start before Monday's chaos began. While her colleagues scrambled to catch up with emails and deadlines first thing in the morning, she was already executing her plan. Her manager noticed how consistently calm and prepared she seemed, and asked about her secret. Priya smiled and said it was nothing complicated — just a small habit of beginning before the race officially started. That head start, week after week, quietly built her reputation as the most reliable person on the team.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 다른 사람보다 먼저 출발하거나 미리 시작하는 것.
meaning.realUsageKo: 경쟁이나 과제에서 다른 사람보다 유리한 위치를 선점했을 때 사용한다. 시간적·실력적으로 앞서 나간 상태를 표현할 때 자주 쓰인다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 경마에서 출발 신호 전에 앞서 출발하는 것을 'head start'라고 부른 데서 유래했다. 이후 일상적인 경쟁 상황 전반으로 의미가 확장되었다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 노력이나 준비 덕분에 이미 유리한 위치에 있다는 긍정적 뉘앙스를 지닌다. 특히 경쟁 상황에서 '이미 앞서 있다'는 자신감을 담아 쓰인다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: Starting to save money in your twenties gives you a real head start for retirement.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 20대에 저축을 시작하면 은퇴 준비에서 확실히 유리한 출발을 할 수 있어.
